Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies [40 CFR 68.155(a)]

Actagro Osceola facility's commitment to providing a safe, healthy work environment for employees as well as providing a safe, healthy environment for the surrounding community is strongly supported by senior management and is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as employee training and in considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility.



The properties of anhydrous ammonia make it necessary to observe specific safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to facility personnel, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. The facility implements both administrative and engineering controls to reasonably minimize the risk of an uncontrolled release of anhydrous ammonia and has not had nor does it anticipate having any type of uncontrolled release.



Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances [40 CFR 68.155(b)]

Actagro operates a crop nutrient manufacturing facility which utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a raw material. The manufacturing process begins with leonardite (a soft coal rich in humin fractions) which is chemically reacted with anhydrous ammonia, phosphoric acid and the organic acids found in the leonardite to develop mixed grade fertilizers used in the production of crop nutrients for resale.



Anhydrous ammonia is received by tanker truck and stored in two (2) 12,000 gallon above ground bullet storage tanks at the site with the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia stored on location is limited to 80% level of the storage bullet tanks, or 99,300 pounds.



There are no listed flammable substances which exceed their respective threshold quantities stored at this facility.



General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]

The Osceola facility is subject to the EPA Chemical Accident P

revention Provisions (40 CFR 68) as a Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) because the worst-case release scenario poses an offsite public impact risk. The Osceola facility is also regulated under the OSHA Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR 1910.119) (PSM) Program for the prevention of hazardous chemical releases in the workplace. The facility complies with the Program 3 requirements of EPA's RMP rule through the implementation of the OSHA PSM Program. The PSM prevention program consists of the following elements:



? Employee Participation: This program involves the employees, in participation in establishing and implementing the program. Employees are involved when a process hazard analysis is conducted. The program ensures employees have complete access to the program.

? Process Safety Information (PSI): Written information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the process. The written information includes SDS's and a description of the design of the anhydrous ammonia containing process.

? Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): Formal studies using the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) methodology have been conducted to look at the process and identify potential hazards.

? Operating Procedures: Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps which should be followed to safely operate the anhydrous ammonia process.

? Employee Training: A training program has been developed which ensures employees are trained on aspects of the process and on the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the anhydrous ammonia process.

? Contractor Safety: Contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the anhydrous ammonia process. The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure they follow safe-work practices.

? Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review is completed for new anhydrous ammonia project

s to verify safety programs are in place, training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put into use.

? Mechanical Integrity: The facility has developed and implemented procedures to ensure the anhydrous ammonia process is built and maintained using preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.

? Hot Work Permit: The facility has developed and implemented procedures to ensure a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning activities.

? Management of Change: The facility has developed and implemented a Management of Change (MOC) program to ensure changes made to the anhydrous ammonia process are properly reviewed.

? Incident Investigation: The facility has developed and implemented procedures to ensure incidents (and near misses) involving the anhydrous ammonia process are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an investigation team.

? Compliance Audits: The facility conducts audits of the prevention program every 3 years (or sooner if needed) to ensure the program is in place and working properly.



5 Year Accident History [40 CFR 68.155(d)]

The Actagro Osceola facility has no history of releases of listed Hazardous Substances which have resulted in offsite effects.



Emergency Response Program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]

Actagro maintains an Emergency Action Plan, in lieu of an Emergency Response Program. Their policy is to contact the local fire department in the event of a hazardous chemical release. Actagro has coordinated with the local fire department, and in the unlikely event of an uncontrolled release, the local authorities will be notified by Actagro and the local authorities will decide on whether local areas will be evacuated. The local authorities will notify any affected neighbors or surrounding properties if an evacuation is necessary.



Since the Actagro facility is included in the community emergency response plan a

nd maintains appropriate mechanisms to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response, according to 40 CFR 68.90, the facility does not have to comply with 40 CFR 68.95 and does not have to develop an emergency response program. Additionally, under 29 CFR 1910.120(l)(1)(ii), employers who will evacuate their employees from the danger area when an emergency occurs, and who do not permit any of their employees to assist in handling the emergency, are exempt from the requirements of this paragraph if they provide an emergency action plan complying with 29 CFR 1910.38.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]

Actagro is committed to continuous efforts to improve the safe operation of the anhydrous ammonia process by implementing preventative maintenance programs, inspection programs, and employee training in the safe operation of the equipment and the process. The anhydrous ammonia process is designed in accordance with good engineering practices. Periodic auditing of the PSM Program ensures process changes or modifications are evaluated and necessary safety precautions and/or safety improvements are made before the process is placed into operation.
